variant.question:

 2\. Procedures

options.text: CAT I minima.
LPV (localiser performance with vertical guidance) minima.
LNAV/VNAV minima.
LNAV minima.

options.text: All stages of the flight, for terrain clearance.
Final approach segment.
Initial and final approach segments.
Initial and intermediate approach segments.

options.text: Select a minimum descent altitude depending on the outside air temperature.
Describe the final approach path, both laterally and vertically.
Programme the arrival route through waypoints and path terminators.
Feed the GNSS receiver with the differential corrections for the area.

options.text: 20 minutes
5 minutes
10 minutes
30 minutes

options.text: Navigation applications.
Navigation specifications.
NAVAID applications.
NAVAID infrastructures.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

What is the text "RNP 1.00" and "ANP 1.36" indicating?

options.text: The actual navigation performance is permitted to be 35% greater than the RNP.
The aircraft navigation performance is better than required.
The aircraft is 1.36 NM off the track.
The text is amber because the navigation performance is out of limits.

variant.question:
When performing an RNP approach, which of the following situations leads to a missed approach unless sufficient visual contact is established?

1\. Communications failure.   
 2\. TCAS RA.   
 3\. Position fix differs from the other instruments.   
 4\. The actual navigation accuracy exceeds the required navigation accuracy.   
 5\. The lateral deviation exceeds instrument full scale deflection.
ICAO Doc 9613 defines a set of navigation specifications for different airspace concepts. The navigation specification RNP 2 is for:

options.text: Arrival, approach, and departure phases of flight.
En-route, arrival, and departure phases of flight.
The en-route phase of flight in oceanic/remote and continental areas.
Arrival, approach (except for the final approach), and departure phases of flight.

variant.question: Within the Performance Based Navigation concept, RNP requires on-board performance monitoring and alerting. An advanced navigation system such as a Flight Management System (FMS) will assess its own position and calculate an Estimated Position Error (EPE). How can this be achieved?

options.text: The Inertial Reference System (IRS) provides the ultimate reference for the aircraft's position; the position determined by radio navigation will be a measure of the error of the FMS position.
Aircraft with a single FMS will compare the FM position with the IRS position and will use the difference, if any, to calculate a bias that is applied to the FMS position to improve its accuracy.
The FMS will use several sources of navigation information and, depending on their expected accuracy, create a comparison between these position data and the FMS position.
This process requires at least two independent FMSs in order for them to compare each other’s position, thereby calculating a correction to be applied to the FMS positions.

variant.question: What is required to fly an RNP approach to LPV minima?

options.text: LNAV and VNAV capability.
Be equipped with atleast two LRNSs.
Authorisation.
SBAS and FAS data block.

variant.question: During flight, a pilot is alerted that the aircraft's ANP is greater than the RNP. The aircraft's navigational accuracy (1) \_\_\_\_\_ within acceptable limits, as navigational accuracy is defined as the difference between the required aircraft position and its (2) \_\_\_\_\_ position.

options.text: (1) is not; (2) desired
(1) is not; (2) true
(1) is; (2) true
(1) is; (2) desired

variant.question: Regarding the PBN specification RNP AR APCH, what requires specific authorisation?

options.text: Performing an approach without onboard performance monitoring and alerting.
The published instrument approach.
Any arrival route directly to the initial approach fix.
A continuous descent final approach to the final approach fix.

variant.question: Within the PBN concept, "availability" is a measure of the ability of the system to provide usable services within the specified coverage area. It is defined as...

options.text: the capability of the total system, comprising all elements necessary to maintain aircraft position within the defined airspace, to perform its function without non scheduled interruptions during the intended operation.
the ability of a system to provide timely warnings to users when the system should NOT be used for navigation.
a method of navigation that permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path.
the percentage of time during which the system is to be used for navigation during which reliable navigation information is presented.

options.text: RNAV 10 / RNP 10 only
RNP 1 only
RNP 4 and RNP 1 only
RNAV 10 / RNP 10 and RNP 4 only

variant.question: For terminal & en-route phases of flight, PBN is limited to:

options.text: Lateral navigation.
Vertical navigation.
Lateral & Vertical navigation.
Full 3D navigation.

variant.question: The concept of RNP applies...

options.text: to navigation performance within an airspace using satellite navigation systems only.
to navigation performance on RNAV routes only.
to navigation performance within an airspace.
to navigation performance within an airspace and a specific time-interval.

variant.question: Your aircraft is approved to conduct RNP APP. Can you fly RNP 2?

options.text: Yes, because the most restricted procedure contains the least requirements.
Yes, because your aircraft is approved for a more restricted procedure.
Yes, because the requirements for all RNP operations are the same.
No, because your aircraft may not have the requeriments for RNP 2.

variant.question: What is correct for aircraft equipment which operates to RNP 1 and better?

options.text: The equipment should be able to compute the exact value of the aircraft’s position error.
The equipment should be able to correct for the exact value of the aircraft’s position error.
The equipment should be able to correct for an estimated value of the aircraft’s position error.
The equipment should be able to compute an estimated value of the aircraft’s position error.

variant.question: What is the difference between the on-board navigation specifications RNP 1 and RNAV 1?

options.text: A performance-monitoring and alerting function is required for RNP 1 only.
A performance-monitoring function is required for both RNP 1 and RNAV 1\. An alerting function is only required for RNP 1.
A performance-monitoring and alerting function is required for RNAV 1 only.
An alerting function is required for both RNP 1 and RNAV 1\. A performance-monitoring function is only required for RNP 1.

variant.question: Consider PBN operations, what is one advantage of navigating using computed data, compared to raw data? The area navigation system will:

options.text: Provide 3D navigation for the whole route.
Only use data from one sensor for navigation.
Check the validity and in some cases consistency of sensor data before use.
Give a more accurate position, regardless of the sensor data that is being used.

variant.question: What does PBN accommodate in the approach phases of flight?

options.text: Guidance to fly ILS/MLS/GLS procedures.
Linear laterally guided operations only.
Both linear and angular laterally guided operations.
Angular laterally guided operations only.

variant.question: The Performance Based Navigation (PBN) concept uses terms to describe the requirements of each navigation specification. Which of the following terms defines the capability of the system to perform its function without unscheduled interruptions during the intended operation?

options.text: Continuity.
Availability.
Integrity.
Accuracy.

variant.question: According to ICAO Doc 9613, RNAV 5 is a navigation specification that only applies to...

options.text: arrivals, approaches, and departures.
en-route continental navigation as well as arrival and departure routes.
arrivals and departures.
en-route continental navigation and arrival outside 30 NM and above MSA.

variant.question: The FMS can be used to check the Estimated Position Error (EPE) of the FMS position. What does this value mean to the pilot?

options.text: The EPE is the total position error of the aircraft including the Flight Technical Error.
The pilot is able to check that the aircraft follows the track as defined in the database.
The pilot uses this value to assess the Flight Technical Error of the aircraft.
The EPE value must be equal to or less than the required navigation specification.

options.text: Baro-VNAV minima.
CAT II minima.
CAT I, II, II minima.
LNAV minima.

options.text: Navigation application.
Radio Navigation Application - Version 5.
Navigation specification.
Navaid infrastructure.

The pilot must confirm that they are able to maintain the required lateral accuracy along the route.
The equipment must comply to RNAV2/RNP2 specifications.
The pilot and aircraft must be certified for RNP 2, RNP 1 or RNP 0.3.

variant.question: An example of a non-precision approach is...

options.text: LPV.
LNAV.
LNAV/VNAV.
GLS.

options.text: Navigation specification and navigation application.
Navigational aid infrastructure and navigation specification.

variant.question: An aircraft is approved for RNP APCH. Will this mean that it is automatically approved for RNP 2? Why?

options.text: No, because the aircraft may not meet all requirements for RNP 2 approval.
Yes, because RNP 2 is less stringent, so it is automatically included under any stricter approvals.
Yes, because the navigation databases are the same for all RNP flights.
No, because an aircraft can either be approved for RNP 2 or RNP APCH, but it can never be approved for both.

options.text: The RNAV system will command a holding.
The RNAV system will discontinue the offset.
LNAV will disengage and control wheel steering mode will engage.
The aircraft will return to the defined route.

variant.question: RNAV 1 and RNP 1 are used:

options.text: In the departure phases of flight.
In the arrival and departure phases of flight.
In all phases of flight, except for oceanic and remote phases.

variant.question: You are flying in IMC at night above the 73°North latitude. Because of the high latitude and the GNSS satellite positions, you elect to fly an RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minima based on barometric VNAV with GNSS horizontal guidance. The minimum published temperature for the approach is -8°C, and your aircraft does not have automatic temperature-compensation fitted. The temperature given by the most recent ATIS is -6°C. During final approach, ATC tells you to make an immediate go around because terrain separation is no longer guaranteed. What is the most likely reason for losing minimum terrain separation?

options.text: The wrong QNH was given, leading to reduced terrain separation due to indicated altitude being higher than true altitude.
Incorrect FMS setup.
The temperature has increased above the limiting value.
The wrong VNAV barometric data for the given conditions is being used.

variant.question: Which statement is correct regarding the effect of outside conditions on a baro-VNAV approach?

options.text: In cold air the true altitude will be greater than indicated.
In cold air the glide slope will be shallower.
In hot air the glide slope will be shallower.
In hot air the true altitude will be lower than indicated.

options.text: En-route continental, arrival, and departure.
En-route oceanic, en-route continental, and approach.

options.text: SBAS or baro-VNAV
GLS or SBAS
Radio altimeter or baro-VNAV ​​​​​​

variant.question: What is the difference between an RNAV SID and an RNAV overlay SID?

options.text: The RNAV overlay SID will follow the same track as the conventional procedure.
The RNAV overlay SID will take more time due to less constraints.
The RNAV overlay SID is a longer route than the RNAV SID.
The RNAV overlay SID will take less time due to less constraints.

variant.question: According to the Definition from Annex I to Part-FCL regarding linear and angular laterally guided operations during approach phases of flight, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Linear guidance means instrument approach operation in which the maximum tolerable error/deviation from the planned track is expressed in units of length, for instance nautical miles, for cross-track lateral deviation.

Angular guidance means instrument approach operation in which the maximum tolerable error/deviation from the planned track is expressed in percent of maximum deviation distance for cross-track lateral deviation.

Angular guidance means instrument approach operation in which the maximum tolerable error/deviation from the planned track is expressed in units of length, for instance nautical miles, for cross-track lateral deviation.

Linear guidance means instrument approach operation in which the maximum tolerable error/deviation from the planned track is expressed in terms of deflection of the needles on the Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) or equivalent display in the cockpit.

variant.question: What does the abbreviation AR mean in RNP AR APCH?

options.text: Authorisation Required
Approach Restriction
Automatic Reversion
Arrival Restriction

variant.question: For PBN operations, what is correct regarding fly-by waypoints and fly-over waypoints?

options.text: Fly-over waypoints use turn anticipation but fly-by waypoints do not.
For fly-by waypoints, the turn to the next course is commenced when overhead the waypoint, and for fly-over waypoints the turn is commenced prior to reaching the waypoint.
For fly-by waypoints, the turn is commenced prior to reaching the waypoint, and for fly-over waypoints the turn is commenced when overhead the waypoint.
Fly-by waypoints use turn anticipation whereas fly-over waypoints require the pilot to turn 30 seconds before or after reaching the waypoint.

variant.question: What is the Required Navigation Performance (RNP) based on?

options.text: The number of satellites available to perform RAIM.
The accuracy of commercially available Inertial Navigation Systems.
The horizontal position accuracy to be achieved within an airspace.

two LRNSs comprising an INS, an IRS FMS or a GNSS.

one calendar month

variant.question: In PBN operations, both linear and angular lateral guidance can be used in the approach phase of flight, depending on the procedure and minima. The maximum allowable error or deviation from the planned track in this phase of flight is expressed in...

options.text: degrees needle deflection on the Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) for linear operation and cross-track lateral deviation in nautical miles for angular operation.
nautical miles for along track deviation for linear operation and in degrees needle deflection on the Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) for angular operation in the vertical plane.
nautical miles for cross track lateral deviation for linear operation and in degrees needle deflection on the Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) for angular operation.
degrees needle deflection on the Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) for both linear and angular operation.

variant.question: An aircraft equipped with RNAV 1 navigation specifications is cleared by the ATC to execute a Standard Instrument Departure (SID) that requires RNP 1 equipment. The pilot is not qualified for RNP 1 procedures, and the aircraft is not equipped with RNP 1\. What should the pilot do?

options.text: He/she shall accept the SID, since the requirement for lateral accuracy is assured.
Advise ATC, that he/she is UNABLE to comply and should request a different SID.
He/she shall accept the SID and monitor system performance during departure.
He/she should first check the integrity of the system and then advise ATC accordingly.

variant.question: RNP 1 could be used for:

options.text: En-route continental only.
En-route and arrival applications mainly.
Oceanic and remote continental navigation applications only.

Manually, by inserting range and bearing to a new waypoint, in response to an ATC clearance.
By inserting or deleting waypoints in the flight plan, in response to an ATC clearance.
It is not possible.

The following Instrument Approach Operations are classified as 3D Approach Operations:

options.text: The correction applied to position when using an augmentation system.
The distance between the GNSS position and calculated actual position.
An error calculated in the control segment and broadcast on the navigation message.

options.text: RNAV 10 to RNP 1.

RNP AR to RNP 0.3.
RNAV 5 to RNAV 1.

variant.question: An aircraft is making a 2D (LNAV) approach under IMC, to an aerodrome where the temperature is significantly different from ISA. Which of the following is correct regarding temperature corrections to the MDA?

options.text: The Pilot-In-Command is responsible for making a correction if the temperature is much lower than ISA.
The Controller will pass on a correction when the temperature is much lower than ISA.
The Controller will pass on a correction when the temperature is much higher than ISA.
The Pilot-In-Command is responsible for making a correction if the temperature is much higher than ISA.

variant.question: You are approaching an aerodrome on an RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minima using baro-VNAV. The approach has a minimum temperature of -8ºC. The OAT is +10ºC, during final approach, ATC tells you to go around immediately due to loss of terrain separation. What could have happened?

options.text: GBAS signal has been lost.
You made a mistake inputting barometric data.
RAIM error.
Loss of the GNSS signal because of the low satellite elevations above the horizon.

variant.question: During descent ATC informs the pilot to expect the RNP Approach (RNP APCH) for Runway 09\. During approach preparation the pilot notices that one waypoint of the RNP APCH is missing in the navigation database. What are his/her options?

options.text: An RNP APCH must NOT be flown unless it is retrievable from the on-board navigation database and conforms to the charted procedure. Request a different approach procedure from ATC.
Create a new RNP APCH procedure for Runway 09 in the on-board navigation database. Check that all data conform to the charted procedures and continue the approach.
An RNP APCH is permitted to be flown even if it is NOT retrievable from the on-board navigation database, so long as it is being backed up by other means of navigation. Continue the approach.

Load the existing RNP APCH procedure for Runway 09 from the on-board navigation database and insert the missing waypoint manually. Check that all data conform to the charted procedures and continue the approach.

in the en-route continental, arrival and departure phases of flight.

in all phases of flight.

options.text: Hot temperatures cause a decrease in the glide path angle.
Cold temperatures cause a higher elevation.

variant.question: In the context of PBN operations, what is “Navigation System Error (NSE)”?

options.text: NSE occurs when the path defined in the RNAV system does NOT correspond to the desired path, that is, the path expected to be flown over the ground.
It refers to the difference between the aircraft’s estimated position and its actual position.
NSE is part of the total system error, which relates to the air crew or autopilot’s ability to follow the defined path or track, including any display error.
It is a system error that relates specifically to longitudinal accuracy.

variant.question: In PBN operations, on-board performance monitoring and alerting of the Path Definition Error (PDE):

options.text: Measures the difference between the aircraft's estimated position and its true position, and the crew are alerted if PDE is greater than the RNP specification.
Is achieved by monitoring the aircraft's performance and alerting the crew if the aircraft's navigation system fails to perform accurately.
Depends on the integrity of the navigation database, and PDE is assumed to be zero.
Is managed by crew procedures in order to monitor the aircraft's position.

options.text: LNAV/VNAV
Horizontal guidance
Vertical guidance
3D guidance

variant.question: An aircraft NOT equipped with temperature-compensating system is executing an RNP APCH to a Baro-VNAV minimum. The minimum temperature to execute the procedure (TMIN) is -8°C. The pilots miscalculated the rate of descent and selected an inappropriate vertical speed.
The temperature at the aerodrome is above the limiting temperature.
The vertical path in the FMS was incorrectly coded as it is NOT shown to the pilots.

variant.question: What is an "ARINC 424 Path Terminator" in reference to Performance Based Navigation?

It is the point at which an RNAV specification segment of a procedure changes to another RNAV specification.

variant.question: Your aircraft is approved for RNP APCH (LNAV). Therefore, it will automatically also be approved for RNP2 operations as they require a lower level of accuracy to RNP APCH (LNAV). Is this statement correct?

options.text: Yes, because an operational approval is NOT required for either of the operations.
Yes, on condition that the pilot holds a valid instrument rating including privilege to fly PBN operations.
No, as the aircraft may fail to meet all the functional requirements for RNP2\. A separate approval for RNP 2 is necessary.
Yes, an approval for RNP with strict accuracy requirements covers either RNP specifications with lower accuracy requirements.

variant.question: SBAS is required to comply with the PBN specifications for RNP approaches down to:

options.text: LNAV minima.
LPV minima.
Baro-VNAV minima.

variant.question: What is the name of a specific, curved flight path in a terminal or approach procedure that is defined by radius, arc length, and fix?

options.text: Fixed radius transition.
Fly-by turn.
Radius to fix leg.
Offset flight path.

variant.question: Within the PBN concept, what is the flight technical error?

options.text: FTE is the difference between the aircraft's estimated position and its actual position.
It is part of the total system error, which relates to the air crew or autopilot's ability to follow the defined path or track, including any display error.
It is a system error that relates to longitudinal accuracy.
FTE occurs when the path defined in the RNAV system does NOT correspond to the desired path, that is the path expected to be flown over the ground.

variant.question: An aircraft is flying RNAV 2 and another aircraft is flying RNP 2\. What is the difference between them?

options.text: RNP 2 is used in the en-route and oceanic/remote phases of flight. RNAV 2 is used in oceanic phases of flights or over remote areas
RNP 2 is used on arrival and departure phases of flight. RNAV 2 is used in the en-route and oceanic/remote phases of flight.
RNP 2 is used in the en-route and oceanic/remote phases of flight. RNAV 2 might be used in the en-route continental, arrival and departure phases of flight.
RNP 2 might be used in the en-route continental, arrival and departure phases of flight. RNAV 2 is used in the en-route and oceanic/remote phases of flight

variant.question: Which navigation error(s) of an on-board Required Navigation Performance (RNP) system can be monitored by the pilot?

options.text: Flight Technical Error (FTE) only
Flight Technical Error (FTE), Navigation System Error (NSE)
Earth Rate Error(ERE), Flight Technical Error (FTE)
Total System Error (TSE), Flight Technical Error (FTE)

variant.question: An operator operates multiple of the same type of aircraft. However, some of the aircraft are able to fly to LPV (Localizer performance with vertical guidance) minima while others are not able to do so. The reason for this difference in capability is that the…

options.text: ILS, SBAS and/or GBAS signals are NOT integrated to achieve a similar performance standard.
FMS requires a localiser and glideslope input from the ILS receiver in order to achieve ILS Performance.
ILS receiver does NOT include the enhanced localiser and glideslope function for CAT III Operations.
FMS requires an additional final approach segment (FAS) data block function to fly LPV minima.

variant.question: In which route segment may RNAV 5 be used?

options.text: Arrival and en-route outside 30 NM and above MSA.
Arrival, approaches and departure.
Arrivals and departures.
En-route continental navigation as well as arrival and departure routes.

variant.question: Lateral offset flightpath in RNAV/RNP…

options.text: is possible during the entire route and also in approach phases.
is possible in increments of 1 NM up to 20 NM.
is achieved by a 45 degree offset from track.
is possible only on the left side of track.

variant.question: What should an aircraft that operates to RNP1 or better be able to do?

options.text: Correct exact value of aircraft position error.
Compute exact value of aircraft position error.
Correct estimated value of aircraft position error.
Compute estimated value of aircraft position error.

variant.question: When conducting an RNP APCH TO LNAV/VNAV minima, an aircraft's lateral guidance is based on GNSS and its vertical guidance can be based on either…

options.text: GBAS or SBAS.
SBAS or Baro-VNAV.
GBAS or Rad alt.
Rad Alt or Baro-VNAV.

variant.question:
According to the ICAO PBN Manual, in order to satisfy the following strategic objectives: safety, capacity, efficiency, environment and access; the "airspace concept" has been developed. This is achieved by enhancements in:

(1) Communications (COM)   
(2) Navigation (NAV)   
(3) Surveillance (SUR)   
(4) Air Traffic Management (ATM)

PBN 3D approaches are:

1\. GNSS + VNAV   
2\. GLS   
3\. PAR   
4\. RNP 1   
5\. ILS   
6\. SBAS

options.text: 1 and 6.

variant.question: Considering PBN procedures, which of the following RNP/RNAV specifications allows the pilot to manually define waypoints not already in the FMS database?

options.text: RNAV 2
RNAV 5
RNP 1
RNP APCH

variant.question:
In the PBN concept, the Total System Error is made up of which of the following errors?

1\. Path Definition Error (PDE)   
 2\. Path Calculation Error (PCE)   
 3\. Flight Crew Error (FCE)   
 4\. Navigation System Error (NSE)   
 5\. Flight Technical Error (FTE)   
 6\. Path Terminator Error (PTE)

options.text: 1, 2 and 3
4, 5 and 6
2, 3 and 6
1, 4 and 5

variant.question: Are operators with aircraft equipped with a single IRS or INS permitted to extend their RNAV 10 capability time?

options.text: Yes, they can extend their time by applying to the State of Registration.
No, this is not possible.
Yes they can extend their time by fitting two IRS systems.
Yes, they can extend their time by updating.

variant.question: For PBN operations, what is true regarding fly-by turns and fly-over turns?

options.text: Fly-by waypoints are used when the aircraft must first fly over the waypoint before starting a turn.
Fly-by and fly-over waypoints are compatible with both RNAV and RNP flight tracks.
The fly-by turn can be used in RNP flight tracks but fly-over turns are excluded.
Pilots can change a route database waypoint type from a fly-by to a fly-over.

variant.question: Plotting positions in charts by Dead Reckoning (DR) may be required..

options.text: during a flight with limited equipment and few navigational aids.
during a flight over sea using INS/IRS and GPS navigation.
in areas with high densities of airways and navigation aids.
when any of the radio-navigation, INS or GPS sources are unavailable.

variant.question: An error during PBN operations in the accuracy of determining actual aircraft coordinates is a:

options.text: Crew Coordination Error (CCE)
Path Definition Error (PDE)
Flight Technical Error (FTE)
Navigation System Error (NSE)

variant.question: Consider RNAV and RNP system functions. An “offset flight path’’ is:

options.text: A parallel path that is offset only to the left of the original active route.
A lateral offset from a defined route, which is specified in increments of 1 NM up to 20 NM.
A variable lateral offset from a defined route that can be applied for the entire length of the route, including the approach procedure.
A lateral offset from a defined route, and the offset must be intercepted at an angle of 45 degrees or more.

variant.question: The PBN concept specifies that aircraft RNAV and RNP system performance requirements are to be defined in terms of:

options.text: Accuracy, integrity and continuity.
The navigation equipment, integrity and functionality.
The procedures, accuracy and redundancy.
The procedures, accuracy and integrity.

variant.question: An RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minima based on BARO-VNAV can only be conducted when the aircraft is within a promulgated temperature range. What is the reason for this?

options.text: Static vents can be blocked due to icing when approaching in IMC, hence leading to a loss of vertical guidance.
The calculated true air speed (TAS) is based on the standard atmosphere and any significant differences will lead to an approach speed which could be too slow or too fast.
The difference between true height and published decision height has to be limited to a maximum value.
The assessment of the vertical position of the aircraft, in relation to the glide path angle (GPA) during the approach is based on barometric data.

variant.question: What is correct for PDE (Path Definition Error)?

options.text: It relates to the air crew or autopilot’s ability to follow the defined path or track.
The RNAV calculated aircraft coordinates corresponds to the actual aircraft coordinates.
Path defined by RNAV system corresponds to the desired path.
Path defined by RNAV system does not correspond to the desired path.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

The appendix shows a navigation display (ND) where the Required Navigation Performance (RNP) and Actual Navigation Performance (ANP) values are shown. Which of the following statements is a correct interpretation of these displayed values.

options.text: The aircraft is 0.05 NM offset to the left of the track and the maximum limit is a 2.00 NM offset.
The aircraft is currently performing according to the RNP, but a warning will be given if the ANP increases beyond 2.00.
During the cruise phase, there shall be NO warning if the ANP value is 0.05 higher than the RNP value as RNP 2 applies to the approach phase.
The navigation system is performing to an accuracy of 2.00 NM and the aeroplane is within 0.05 NM of the desired track.

variant.question: How may pilots retrieve an RNAV / RNP1 / RNP2 SID or STAR for use?

options.text: Retrievable by route name from the on-board navigation database and conforms to the charted route.
Selecting a route, from the company database, which will automatically choose the SID.
Manually by entering name of the SID STAR Route.
Manually by entering LONG and LAT coordinates.

variant.question: An RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minima has lateral guidance based on GNSS and vertical guidance based on:

options.text: A method which is certified for the purpose.
Only a barometric input.
GBAS
The Radio Altimeter.

variant.question: What do PBN path terminators define?

options.text: A specific type of termination of RNP or RNAV procedures.
A specific type of termination of the previous flight path.

A specific type of termination of ATC clearances.

​​
A specific type of termination of a flight plan.

variant.question: For oceanic/remote, en-route, and terminal phases of flight, PBN is limited to..

options.text: operations with linear lateral performance requirements and time constraints.
ILS/MLS/GLS precision approach and landing operations.
operations with angular lateral performance requirements and time constraints.
both linear and angular laterally guided operations.

variant.question: What is the correct statement regarding baro-VNAV?

options.text: Cold temperature reduces the effective glide path angle.
Hot temperature reduces the effective glide path angle.
Hot temperature makes the aircraft lower than indicated.
Cold temperature makes the aircraft higher than indicated.

variant.question:
An aeroplane is following a terminal procedure requiring the use of RNP 1\. The following message appears on the Navigation Display (ND) accompanied by an aural signal:

"NAV ACCUR DOWNGRAD"

What is the significance of this message?

options.text: The navigation accuracy is less than required accuracy of +/- 1 NM.
Some GNSS signals have been lost and RAIM is no longer available.
The aeroplane is outside the coverage of navigation aids.
The FMS position is now based on the IRS position alone; EPE may be less than 1 NM.

variant.question: According to ICAO Doc 9613, a specific form of fixed radius path (FRP) is designed for utilization in en-route procedures. This particular FRP relies on the RNP system to establish the fixed radius turn between two route segments. In ICAO terminology, this form of FRP is referred to as...

options.text: Fly-by (FB) turn.
Fix-radius Transition (FRT).
Radius to fix (RF) leg.
Radius leg (RL).

variant.question: What PBN will be used for North Atlantic High Level operations (NAT HLA)?

options.text: RNAV10/RNP 10, RNP4 only.
RNP4-RNP1 only.
RNAV 2-RNAV 1 only.
RNAV 1 only.

variant.question: The pilot notices that the ANP is 1.24 and the RNP is 1.00\. What does that mean?

options.text: ANP is always greater than RNP.
Insufficient data to determine accuracy.
Accuracy out of limit.
Accuracy within acceptable limits.
